sentences.sentence: The strangest thing was that, almost before he had looked about him, Digory had half forgotten how he had come there.
At any rate, he was certainly not thinking about Polly, or Uncle Andrew, or even his Mother.
He was not in the least frightened, or excited, or curious.
If anyone had asked him “Where did you come from?” he would probably have said, “I’ve always been here.”
That was what it felt like—as if one had always been in that place and never been bored although nothing had ever happened.
As he said long afterwards( 之后 ), “It’s not the sort of place where things happen. The trees go on growing, that’s all.”
After Digory had looked at the wood for a long time he noticed that there was a girl lying on her back at the foot of a tree a few yards away.
Her eyes were nearly shut but not quite, as if she were just between sleeping and waking.
So he looked at her for a long time and said nothing.
And at last she opened her eyes and looked at him for a long time and she also said nothing.
Then she spoke, in a dreamy( 迷人的 ), contented sort of voice.
“I think I’ve seen you before,” she said.
“I rather think so too,” said Digory. “Have you been here long?”
“Oh, always,” said the girl. “At least—I don’t know—a very long time.”
“So have I,” said Digory.
“No you haven’t, said she. “I’ve just seen you come up out of that pool.”
“Yes, I suppose I did,” said Digory with a puzzled( 困惑的 ) air( 神态 ). “I’d forgotten.”
Then for quite a long time neither said any more.
“Look here,” said the girl presently, “I wonder did we ever really meet before?
I had a sort of idea—a sort of picture in my head—of a boy and a girl, like us—living somewhere quite different—and doing all sorts of things.
Perhaps it was only a dream.”
“I’ve had that same dream, I think,” said Digory. “About a boy and a girl, living next door—and something about crawling( 爬 ) among rafters( 椽子 ).
I remember the girl had a dirty face.”
“Aren’t you getting it mixed? In my dream it was the boy who had the dirty face.”
“I can’t remember the boy’s face,” said Digory, and then added, “Hullo! What’s that?”
“Why! It’s a guinea-pig( 豚鼠 ),” said the girl.
And it was—a fat guinea-pig( 豚鼠 ), nosing about( 搜寻 ) in the grass.
But round the middle of the guinea-pig( 豚鼠 ) there ran a tape, and, tied on to it by the tape, was a bright yellow ring.
“Look! Look,” cried Digory. “The ring! And look! You’ve got one on your finger. And so have I.”
The girl now sat up, really interested at last.
They stared very hard at one another, trying to remember.
And then, at exactly the same moment, she shouted out “Mr. Ketterley” and he shouted out “Uncle Andrew,”
and they knew who they were and began to remember the whole story.
After a few minutes of hard talking they had got it straight. Digory explained how beastly( 令人厌恶的 ) Uncle Andrew had been.
“What do we do now?” said Polly. “Take the guinea-pig( 豚鼠 ) and go home?”
“There’s no hurry,” said Digory with a huge yawn( 打哈欠 ).
“I think there is,” said Polly. “This place is too quiet. It’s so—so dreamy( 做梦般的 ). You’re almost asleep.
If we once give in to it we shall just lie down and drowse( 打瞌睡 ) forever and ever( 永远 ).”
“It’s very nice here,” said Digory.
“Yes, it is,” said Polly. “But we’ve got to get back.” She stood up and began to go cautiously( 小心翼翼地 ) toward the guinea-pig( 豚鼠 ).
But then she changed her mind.
“We might as well leave the guinea-pig( 豚鼠 ),” she said. “It’s perfectly happy here, and your uncle will only do something horrid( 令人讨厌的 ) to it if we take it home.
“I bet( 打赌 ) he would,” answered Digory. “Look at the way he’s treated us. By the way, how do we get home?”
“Go back into the pool, I expect.”
They came and stood together at the edge looking down into the smooth water.
It was full of the reflection of the green, leafy branches; they made it look very deep.
“We haven’t any bathing things,” said Polly.
“We shan’t need them, silly,” said Digory. “We’re going in with our clothes on.
Don’t you remember it didn’t wet us on the way up?”
“Can you swim?”
“A bit. Can you?”
“Well—not much.”
“I don’t think we shall need to swim,” said Digory. “We want to go down, don’t we?”
Neither of them much liked the idea of jumping into that pool, but neither said so to the other.
They took hands and said “One—Two—Three—Go” and jumped.
There was a great splash( 水花飞溅 ) and of course they closed their eyes.
But when they opened them again they found they were still standing, hand in hand, in the green wood, and hardly up to their ankles( 脚踝 ) in water.
The pool was apparently only a couple of inches deep.
They splashed( 蹚水 ) back onto the dry ground.
“What's on earth gone wrong?” said Polly in a frightened voice; but not quite so frightened as you might expect,
because it is hard to feel really frightened in that wood. The place is too peaceful.
“Oh! I know,” said Digory, “Of course it won’t work. We’re still wearing our yellow rings.
They’re for the outward( 向外的 ) journey, you know. The green ones take you home. We must change rings. Have you got pockets?
Good. Put your yellow ring in your left. I’ve got two greens. Here’s one for you.”
They put on their green rings and came back to the pool. But before they tried another jump Digory gave a long “O-o-oh!”
“What’s the matter?” said Polly.
“I’ve just had a really wonderful idea,” said Digory. “What are all the other pools?”
“How do you mean?”
“Why, if we can get back to our own world by jumping into this pool, mightn’t we get somewhere else by jumping into one of the others?
Supposing there was a world at the bottom of every pool.”
“But I thought we were already in your Uncle Andrew’s Other World or Other Place or whatever he called it. Didn’t you say—”
“Oh bother( 讨厌 ) Uncle Andrew,” interrupted Digory. “I don’t believe he knows anything about it.
He never had the pluck( 勇气 ) to come here himself. He only talked of one Other World. But suppose there were dozens?”
“You mean, this wood might be only one of them?”
“No, I don’t believe this wood is a world at all. I think it’s just a sort of in-between place.”
Polly looked puzzled( 困惑的 ). “Don’t you see?” said Digory. “No, do listen. Think of our tunnel( 隧道 ) under the slates( 石板 ) at home. It isn't a room in any of the houses.
In a way, it isn’t really part of any of the houses.
But once you’re in the tunnel( 隧道 ) you can go along it and come out into any of the houses in the row.
Mightn’t this wood be the same?—a place that isn’t in any of the worlds, but once you’ve found that place you can get into them all.”
“Well, even if you can—” began Polly, but Digory went on as if he hadn’t heard her.
“And of course that explains everything,” he said. “That’s why it is so quiet and sleepy here.
Nothing ever happens here. Like at home.
It’s in the houses that people talk, and do things, and have meals.
Nothing goes on in the in-between places, behind the walls and above the ceilings( 天花板 ) and under the floor, or in our own tunnel( 隧道 ).
But when you come out of our tunnel( 隧道 ) you may find yourself in any house.
I think we can get out of this place into jolly well( 无疑，当然 ) anywhere!
We don’t need to jump back into the same pool we came up by. Or not just yet.”

article_info.previous: Uncle Andrew告诉Digory要想救Polly，就得有个人戴着黄色戒指从这个世界先消失，再用绿色戒指从另一个世界回来。但是Uncle Andrew并不确定这能否成功。情急之下，Digory戴上戒指进入了另一个世界。

article_info.share_words: The girl now sat up, really interested at last. They stare very hard at one another, trying to remember.

question.cn: Digory在树林里遇见的女孩是谁？
question.en: Who was the girl that Digory met in the wood?

analysis: 文中提到：“They stared very hard at one another, trying to remember. And then, at exactly the same moment, she shouted out “Mr. Ketterley” and he shouted out “Uncle Andrew,” and they knew who they were and began to remember the whole story. ”可以判断出，这个女孩就是Polly，因此选B。

question.cn: Polly和Digory在草丛里发现了什么动物？
question.en: What animal did Polly and Digory discover in the grass?

analysis: 文中提到：“What’s that?...It was a fat guinea-pig there nosing about in the grass.”由此可知，他们在草丛里发现了一只胖胖的豚鼠，因此选C。

question.cn: 他们怎么处置发现的豚鼠?
question.en: How did Polly and Digory deal with the guinea-pig they found?

analysis: 文中提到Polly说：“We might as well leave the guinea-pig…it’s perfectly happy here, and your uncle will only do something horrid to it if we take it home.”由此可知Polly和Digory担心Uncle Andrew会虐待豚鼠，所以决定把它留在这个地方，因此选B。

options.en: Yes, she could swim very well.

analysis: 文中提到Digory在询问Polly是否会游泳时，Polly说道：“Well, not much.”因此选C。

question.cn: 当Polly和Digory准备回家时，他们是一次成功的吗？
question.en: When Polly and Digory decided to go home, did they succeed at once?

analysis: 文中提到：“There was a great splash and of course they closed their eyes. But when opened them again they found they were still standing. . . they splashed back onto the dry ground.”因此得知Polly和Digoy并没有一次就回家成功，因此选B。
